original: Ekissāpi dattiyā yāpeti, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpeti … sattahipi dattīhi yāpeti.
analyzed: ekissā api dattiyā yāpeti dvīhi pi dattīhi yāpeti  sattahi pi dattīhi yāpeti
translated: He gets by on one bowlful a day, on two bowlfuls a day … on seven bowlfuls a day.

original: Ekāhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti, dvīhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti … sattāhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti. Iti evarūpaṁ addhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.🔽So sākabhakkho vā hoti, sāmākabhakkho vā hoti, nīvārabhakkho vā hoti, daddulabhakkho🔽vā hoti, haṭabhakkho vā hoti, kaṇabhakkho vā hoti, ācāmabhakkho vā hoti, piññākabhakkho
analyzed: ekāhikam pi āhāram āhāreti dvīhikam pi āhāram āhāreti  sattāhikam pi āhāram āhāreti iti evarūpam addhamāsikam pi pariyāya bhatta bhojana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ viharati  so sāka bhakkhaḥ vā hoti sāmāka bhakkhaḥ vā hoti nīvāra bhakkhaḥ vā hoti daddula bhakkhaḥ  vā hoti haṭa bhakkhaḥ vā hoti kaṇa bhakkhaḥ vā hoti ācāma bhakkhaḥ vā hoti piññāka bhakkho
translated: or he eats once every fifteen days, once a month, once every forty-five days, or once every two months.🔽He eats herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, rice-bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung.

original: vā hoti, tiṇabhakkho vā hoti, gomayabhakkho vā hoti, vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī.🔽So sāṇānipi dhāreti, masāṇānipi dhāreti, chavadussānipi dhāreti, paṁsukūlānipi dhāreti,🔽tirīṭānipi dhāreti, ajinampi dhāreti, ajinakkhipampi dhāreti, kusacīrampi dhāreti,
analyzed: vā hoti tiṇa bhakkhaḥ vā hoti gomaya bhakkhaḥ vā hoti vana mūla phala āhāraḥ yāpeti pavatta phala bhojī  saḥ sāṇāni api dhārā iti masāṇāni api dhārā iti chava dussāni api dhārā iti pasu kūlāni api dhārā iti  tirīṭāni api dhārā iti ajinam pi dhārā iti ajinakkhipam pi dhārā iti kusa cīram pi dhārā iti
translated: He lives off forest roots and fruits, or he eats what he gathers by the roots, in the branches, or in the middle.🔽He wears robes of sunn hemp, of hemp, of discarded rags, or of tree bark.🔽He wears a robe made of hair, of horse-tail feathers, of owls’ wings, or of human hair.

original: vākacīrampi dhāreti, phalakacīrampi dhāreti, kesakambalampi dhāreti, vāḷakambalampi
analyzed: vāka cīram pi dhārā iti phalaka cīram pi dhārā iti kesa kambalam pi dhārā iti vāḷa kambalam pi
translated: He wears a robe made of coarse camel’s hair, of bits of wood, of bark, of antelope hide, or of leather.🔽He wears a robe made of owls’ wings or of human hair.

original: dhāreti, ulūkapakkhampi dhāreti,
analyzed: dhāreti ulūka pakkham pi dhāreti
translated: he wears a robe of human hair;

original: kesamassulocakopi hoti, kesamassulocanānuyogamanuyutto,
analyzed: kesa massu locakaḥ api hoti kesa massu locana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ
translated: he shaves off his hair and beard, and he keeps on doing so;

original: ubbhaṭṭhakopi hoti, āsanapaṭikkhitto,🔽ukkuṭikopi hoti ukkuṭikappadhānamanuyutto,🔽kaṇṭakāpassayikopi hoti, kaṇṭakāpassaye seyyaṁ kappeti,
analyzed: ubbhaṭṭhakaḥ api hoti āsana paṭikkhittaḥ  ukkuṭikaḥ api hoti ukkuṭika padhānam anuyuttaḥ  kaṇṭakāpassayikaḥ api hoti kaṇṭakāpassaye seyyam kappeti
translated: he stands continuously, rejecting seats;🔽he squats continuously, committed to the practice of squatting;🔽he lies on a mat of thorns, making his bed on a mat of thorns;

original: sāyatatiyakampi udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.🔽Iti evarūpaṁ anekavihitaṁ kāyassa ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
analyzed: udakorohana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ viharati  iti evarūpam aneka vihitam kāyassa ātāpana paritāpana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ viharati
translated: he practices bathing in cold water and smearing himself with cold ashes.🔽So he lives devoted to and engaged in these various ways of mortifying and tormenting his body.

original: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: so kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapajjati
translated: With the breakup of the body, after death, he is reborn in hell.

original: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ.
analyzed: idam vuccati bhikkhave dhamma samādānam paccuppanna dukkham ca iva āyatim ca dukkha vipāka
translated: This is called the way of undertaking things that is painful now and ripens in the future as pain.

original: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākaṁ?
analyzed: katamat ca bhikkhave dhamma samādānam paccuppanna dukkham āyatim sukha vipāka
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is the way of undertaking things that is painful now and ripens in the future as pleasure?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pakatiyā tibbarāgajātiko hoti, so abhikkhaṇaṁ rāgajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;🔽pakatiyā tibbadosajātiko hoti, so abhikkhaṇaṁ dosajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;🔽pakatiyā tibbamohajātiko hoti, so abhikkhaṇaṁ mohajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ pakatiyā tibba rāga jātikaḥ hoti saḥ abhikkhaṇam rāga jam dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti  pakatiyā tibba dosa jātikaḥ hoti so abhikkhaṇam dosa jam dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti  pakatiyā tibba moha jātikaḥ hoti so abhikkhaṇam moha jam dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti
translated: There is the case where a person is by nature strong in passion. He often experiences pain & distress accompanied by passion.🔽He is by nature strong in aversion. He often experiences pain & distress accompanied by aversion.🔽He is by nature strong in delusion. He often experiences pain & distress accompanied by delusion.

original: So sahāpi dukkhena, sahāpi domanassena, assumukhopi rudamāno paripuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carati.
analyzed: so saha api dukkhena saha api domanassena assu mukhaḥ api rudamānaḥ paripuṇṇam parisuddham brahmacariyam carati
translated: He practices the holy life with pain & distress, inwardly confused, driving himself with a whip of discernment.

original: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: so kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapajjati
translated: With the break-up of the body, after death, he reappears in a good destination, a heavenly world.

original: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākaṁ.
analyzed: idam vuccati bhikkhave dhamma samādānam paccuppanna dukkham āyatim sukha vipāka
translated: This is called the way of undertaking things that is pleasant now and ripens in the future as pleasure.

original: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhañceva āyatiñca sukhavipākaṁ?
analyzed: kataman ca bhikkhave dhamma samādānam paccuppanna sukham ca iva āyatim ca sukha vipāka
translated: “And what, monks, is the way of undertaking things that is pleasant now and ripens in the future as pleasure?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pakatiyā na tibbarāgajātiko hoti, so na abhikkhaṇaṁ rāgajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ pakatiyā na tibba rāga jātikaḥ hoti saḥ na abhikkhaṇam rāga jam dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti
translated: There is the case where a certain person is not by nature strongly disposed to lust, and so he doesn’t often experience pain & distress born of lust.🔽He is not by nature strongly disposed to aversion, and so he doesn’t often experience pain & distress born of aversion.

original: pakatiyā na tibbadosajātiko hoti, so na abhikkhaṇaṁ dosajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;🔽pakatiyā na tibbamohajātiko hoti, so na abhikkhaṇaṁ mohajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.🔽So vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: pakatiyā na tibba dosa jātikaḥ hoti so na abhikkhaṇam dosa jam dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti  pakatiyā na tibba moha jātikaḥ hoti so na abhikkhaṇam moha jam dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti  saḥ vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: He is not by nature strongly disposed to delusion, and so he doesn’t often experience pain & distress born of delusion.🔽Quite secluded from sensuality, secluded from unskillful qualities, he enters & remains in the first jhāna: rapture & pleasure born of seclusion, accompanied by directed thought & evaluation.🔽With the stilling of directed thoughts & evaluations, he enters & remains in the second jhāna: rapture & pleasure born of concentration, unification of awareness free from directed thought & evaluation—internal assurance.

original: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe…🔽tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
analyzed: vitakka vicārānam vūpasamāḥ ajjhattam sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvam a vitakkam a vicāram samādhi jam pīti sukham dutiyam jhānam  tatiyam jhānam
translated: With the fading of rapture, he remains equanimous, mindful, & alert, and senses pleasure with the body. He enters & remains in the third jhāna, of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous & mindful, he has a pleasant abiding.’

original: catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the abandoning of pleasure & pain—as with the earlier disappearance of elation & distress—he enters & remains in the fourth jhāna: purity of equanimity & mindfulness, neither pleasure nor pain.

original: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: so kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapajjati
translated: With the break-up of the body, after death, he reappears in a good destination, a heavenly world.

original: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhañceva āyatiñca sukhavipākaṁ.
analyzed: idam vuccati bhikkhave dhamma samādānam paccuppanna sukham ca iva āyatim ca sukha vipāka
translated: This is called the way of undertaking things that is pleasant now and ripens in the future as pleasure.

original: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri dhammasamādānānī”ti.
analyzed: imāni kho bhikkhave cattāri dhamma samādānāni iti
translated: These are the four ways of undertaking things.”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: That is what the Blessed One said.

original: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
analyzed: attamanāḥ te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandunti
translated: The bhikkhus were satisfied and delighted in the Blessed One’s words.

original: Cūḷadhammasamādānasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ pañcamaṁ.
analyzed: cūḷa dhamma samādāna suttam niṭṭhitam pañcama
translated: The short exposition of the ways of undertaking things is finished.
